Title: Fastest way showing the limit exists without finding the limit?
AcceptedAnswer:
Not sure if the following fits the requirement to avoid finding the limit, but anyway... Consider the change of variable $$x_n=c_n-\frac{r}{c_n}$$ then $$x_{n+1}=-f(c_n)x_n$$ with $$f(c)=\frac{(r-1)c}{(c+1)(c+r)}$$ Now, for every $c>0$, 
$$(c+1)(c+r)\geqslant(r+1)c$$ hence $$f(c)\leqslant s$$ with $$s=\frac{r-1}{r+1}<1$$ Thus, $$|x_n|\leqslant s^{n-1}\cdot|x_1|$$ which implies that $$x_n\to0$$ hence $$c_n\to\text{____}$$
